DOC.HEAD: Letter Claiming Mail-Bomb Responsibility Appears Authentic, FBI Says
Eds: Diader Rosario is cq in 12th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The FBI believes a letter claiming responsibility for bombings that killed a federal judge and a lawyer is authentic, but agents still know nothing about the organization that sent it. The letter was sent to Atlanta television station WAGA and disclosed Thursday. ``We believe the letter received by WAGA is authentic because it contained information which has not been made known to the public and which is known only to someone closely associated with the construction and mailing of the bombs and to law enforcement,'' said William L. Hinshaw, special agent in charge of the FBI investigation. The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, quoting unidentified sources, reported Friday that the letter contained an identifying code identical to that in follow-up letters sent to the bomb targets. The newspaper didn't elaborate. NAACP Southeastern regional director Earl Shinhoster said a letter sent to his office after a tear-gas bombing, postmarked Aug. 21, also contained that numerical code. He said other letters associated with the bombings also have that code. ``They're all the same,'' he said. ``If you see one, you can rest assured that if there's another one, it also has a code.'' The letter to WAGA referred to the case of Julie Love, a white Atlanta woman who was abducted in July 1988 and whose body was found last summer. Two black men were arrested; one has pleaded guilty to murder and other charges, and the other is awaiting trial. The letter said U.S. Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance and Savannah lawyer Robert Robinson were ``assassinated'' in reprisal for Ms. Love's death. It said ``two more prominent members of the NAACP'' also would be killed in reprisal. Vance was killed at his Alabama home on Dec. 16; Robinson was killed in Savannah two days later. The letter said that any time a black man rapes a white woman in Alabama, Florida or Georgia _ the states served by the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, on which Vance sat _ a federal judge, an attorney and an officer of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Persons would be killed. The FBI in Atlanta asked anyone with information on the group, calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System, to call a hotline established for tips in the case. Agency spokesman Diader Rosario said Friday that some calls had been received since news of the group's letter broke Thursday. The information received so far, however, was ``nothing exciting,'' Rosario said. He refused to provide details. ``Certainly it (the group) is something brand new for us, and another link in the chain,'' Rosario said. The letter also condemned the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for ``granting the blacks' demand for white teachers for their children,'' leading FBI agents to re-interview the lead plaintiff in a 21-year-old school-desegregation case. ``They showed me some of the letters that had been written, and they asked me for names of people that I know who would send letters like that,'' said the plaintiff, Roger Mills, who also is a member of the DeKalb NAACP's executive committee. Mills said he would review his stockpile of hate mail to see whether any of it is similar to the letter sent to WAGA. Benjamin Hooks, the NAACP's executive director, said the threatening letter is intended to intimidate the group, ``to strike fear in our hearts.'' ``It will not succeed. We intend to go about our business, but we will most certainly be taking precautions,'' Hooks said from the NAACP national headquarters in Baltimore.
